sen.j: 飛鳥井 雅綱（あすかい まさつな、長享3年（1489年） - 元亀2年（1571年））は、室町時代後期から戦国時代 (日本)の公家。
sen.e: Masatsuna ASUKAI (1489-1571) was a court noble existing from the late Muromachi Period to the Sengoku period (the period of warring states) (Japan.)
Masatsuna ASUKAI (1489-1571) was a court noble existing from the late Muromachi Period to the Sengoku period (the period of warring states) (Japan.)
Masatsuna ASUKAI (1489-1571) was a court noble existing from the late Muromachi Period to the Sengoku period (the period of warring states) (Japan.)
He was the first son of Masatoshi ASUKAI.
He was the first son of Masatoshi ASUKAI.
He was the first son of Masatoshi ASUKAI.

sen.j: 母は、八幡検校生清法印の女。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of Kengyo (the highest rank of the officials of a temple or a shrine) of Hachiman 生清 Hoin (the highest rank among Buddhist priests.)
His mother was a daughter of Kengyo (the highest rank of the officials of a temple or a shrine) of Hachiman 生清 Hoin (the highest rank among Buddhist priests.)
His mother was a daughter of Kengyo (the highest rank of the officials of a temple or a shrine) of Hachiman Shrine 生清 Hoin (the highest rank among Buddhist priests.)
He was called Masauji (雅氏) and Masakiyo, too.
He was called Masauji (雅氏) and Masakiyo, too.
He was called Masauji (雅氏) and Masakiyo, too.

sen.j: 弟に行雅（浄名坊、阿闍梨）。
sen.e: His younger brother was Yukimasa (Jomeibo, Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest.))
His younger brother was Yukimasa (Jomeibo, Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest.))
His younger brother was Yukimasa (Jomeibo, Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest.))
Juichii (Junior First Rank) Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor.)
Juichii (Junior First Rank) Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor.)
Juichii (Junior First Rank) Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state.)

sen.j: 歌人であり、蹴鞠の大家。
sen.e: He was a waka poet and an expert of kemari (a game played by aristocrats in the Heian period.)
He was a waka poet and an expert of kemari (a game played by aristocrats in the Heian period.)
He was a waka poet and an expert of kemari (a game played by aristocrats in the Heian period.)
He served as Bukedenso (liaison officer between the imperial court and the military government.)
He served as Bukedenso (liaison officer between the imperial court and the military government.)
He served as Bukedenso (liaison officer between the imperial court and the military government.)

sen.j: 子女は、覚澄（安居院僧正）、喜雲、飛鳥井雅春、某（最勝院）、尭慧、宗禎（伊豆国修善寺住持、二卜と号す）、遠山、某（報恩院、水本と号す）、雅厳（僧正、松橋）、重茂、仏光寺経範の妻、朽木晴綱室、目の典侍（正親町天皇典侍）のほかに女子あり。
sen.e: His children were princesses including Kakucho (覚澄) (priest of Ango-in Temple) (安居院僧正,) Kiun (喜雲,) Masaharu ASUKAI, a certain person (Saisho-in Temple), Gyoe, Sotei (宗禎) (a chief priest of Shuzen-ji Temple in Izu no kuni known Nito for go (popular name,) Toyama, a certain person (Hoon-in Temple, Mizumoto (水本) for Go,) 雅厳 (a priest called Matsuhashi (松橋,)) 重茂, wife of Tsunenori, Bukko-ji Temple, Harutsuna KUTSUKI's wife, Me no Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) (Emperor Ogimachi's Naishi no suke) and other daughters.

His children were princesses including Kakucho (覚澄) (priest of Ango-in Temple) (安居院僧正,) Kiun (喜雲,) Masaharu ASUKAI, a certain person (Saisho-in Temple), Gyoe, Sotei (宗禎) (a chief priest of Shuzen-ji Temple in Izu no kuni known Nito for go (popular name,) Toyama, a certain person (Hoon-in Temple, Mizumoto (水本) for Go,) 雅厳 (a priest called Matsuhashi (松橋,)) 重茂, wife of Tsunenori, Bukko-ji Temple, Harutsuna KUTSUKI's wife, Me no Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) (Emperor Ogimachi's Naishi no suke) and other daughters.
sen.cmt: Robert: "a certain person" doesn't quite make sense, is it someone that they do not know the name for?
sen.e: His children included Kakucho (a priest at Ango-in Temple), Kiun, Masaharu ASUKAI, Suesuga (a priest at Saisho-in Temple), Gyoe, Sotei (a chief priest at Shuzen-ji Temple in Izu Province who took the name "Nito"), Toyama, Suegami (a priest at Hoon-in Temple who took the name "Mizumoto"), 雅厳 (a priest who took the name "Matsuhashi"), Omoe, a wife of Tsunenori (a priest at Bukko-ji Temple), Harutsuna KUTSUKI's wife, and Me no Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank who was Emperor Ogimachi's Naishi no suke).
sen.cmt: princesses including→ 削除（僧侶も princess のようになってしまうため）no kuni→Province

sen.j: 永禄6年（1563年）に出家し、法名は高雅。
sen.e: He became a priest in 1563 and his Homyo (a name given to a person who enters the Buddhist priesthood) was Takamasa.
He became a priest in 1563 and his Homyo (a name given to a person who enters the Buddhist priesthood) was Takamasa.
He became a priest in 1563 and his Homyo (a name given to a person who enters the Buddhist priesthood) was Takamasa.
